column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=LAD-AND-GIRL LOVE
#Text=Paul had been many times up to Willey Farm during the autumn .
#Text=He was friends with the two youngest boys .
#Text=Edgar , the eldest , would not condescend at first .
#Text=And Miriam also refused to be approached .
#Text=She was afraid of being set at nought , as by her own brothers .
#Text=The girl was romantic in her soul .
#Text=Everywhere was a Walter Scott heroine being loved by men with helmets or with plumes in their caps .
#Text=She herself was something of a princess turned into a swine-girl in her own imagination .

#Text=And she was afraid lest this boy , who , nevertheless , looked something like a Walter Scott hero , who could paint and speak French , and knew what algebra meant , and who went by train to Nottingham every day , might consider her simply as the swine-girl , unable to perceive the princess beneath ; so she held aloof .
#Text=Her great companion was her mother .
#Text=They were both brown-eyed , and inclined to be mystical , such women as treasure religion inside them , breathe it in their nostrils , and see the whole of life in a mist thereof .

#Text=So to Miriam , Christ and God made one great figure , which she loved tremblingly and passionately when a tremendous sunset burned out the western sky , and Ediths , and Lucys , and Rowenas , Brian de Bois Guilberts , Rob Roys , and Guy Mannerings , rustled the sunny leaves in the morning , or sat in her bedroom aloft , alone , when it snowed .
#Text=That was life to her .
#Text=For the rest , she drudged in the house , which work she would not have minded had not her clean red floor been mucked up immediately by the trampling farm-boots of her brothers .

#Text=She madly wanted her little brother of four to let her swathe him and stifle him in her love ; she went to church reverently , with bowed head , and quivered in anguish from the vulgarity of the other choir-girls and from the common-sounding voice of the curate ; she fought with her brothers , whom she considered brutal louts ; and she held not her father in too high esteem because he did not carry any mystical ideals cherished in his heart , but only wanted to have as easy a time as he could , and his meals when he was ready for them .
#Text=She hated her position as swine-girl .
#Text=She wanted to be considered .

#Text=She wanted to learn , thinking that if she could read , as Paul said he could read , “ Colomba ” , or the “ Voyage autour de ma Chambre ” , the world would have a different face for her and a deepened respect .
#Text=She could not be princess by wealth or standing .
#Text=So she was mad to have learning whereon to pride herself .
#Text=For she was different from other folk , and must not be scooped up among the common fry .
#Text=Learning was the only distinction to which she thought to aspire .
#Text=Her beauty — that of a shy , wild , quiveringly sensitive thing — seemed nothing to her .
#Text=Even her soul , so strong for rhapsody , was not enough .
#Text=She must have something to reinforce her pride , because she felt different from other people .
#Text=Paul she eyed rather wistfully .
#Text=On the whole , she scorned the male sex .
#Text=But here was a new specimen , quick , light , graceful , who could be gentle and who could be sad , and who was clever , and who knew a lot , and who had a death in the family .
#Text=The boy ’s poor morsel of learning exalted him almost sky-high in her esteem .
#Text=Yet she tried hard to scorn him , because he would not see in her the princess but only the swine-girl .
#Text=And he scarcely observed her .
#Text=Then he was so ill , and she felt he would be weak .
#Text=Then she would be stronger than he .
#Text=Then she could love him .
#Text=If she could be mistress of him in his weakness , take care of him , if he could depend on her , if she could , as it were , have him in her arms , how she would love him !
#Text=As soon as the skies brightened and plum-blossom was out , Paul drove off in the milkman ’s heavy float up to Willey Farm .
#Text=Mr. Leivers shouted in a kindly fashion at the boy , then clicked to the horse as they climbed the hill slowly , in the freshness of the morning .
#Text=White clouds went on their way , crowding to the back of the hills that were rousing in the springtime .
#Text=The water of Nethermere lay below , very blue against the seared meadows and the thorn-trees .
#Text=It was four and a half miles ’ drive .
#Text=Tiny buds on the hedges , vivid as copper-green , were opening into rosettes ; and thrushes called , and blackbirds shrieked and scolded .
#Text=It was a new , glamorous world .
#Text=Miriam , peeping through the kitchen window , saw the horse walk through the big white gate into the farmyard that was backed by the oak-wood , still bare .
#Text=Then a youth in a heavy overcoat climbed down .
#Text=He put up his hands for the whip and the rug that the good-looking , ruddy farmer handed down to him .
#Text=Miriam appeared in the doorway .
#Text=She was nearly sixteen , very beautiful , with her warm colouring , her gravity , her eyes dilating suddenly like an ecstasy .
#Text=“ I say , ” said Paul , turning shyly aside , “ your daffodils are nearly out .
#Text=Is n’t it early ? But do n’t they look cold ? ”
#Text=“ Cold ! ” said Miriam , in her musical , caressing voice .
